skill.description: Create publication figures with matplotlib/seaborn/plotly. Multi-panel layouts, error bars, significance markers, colorblind-safe, export PDF/EPS/TIFF, for journal-ready scientific plots.

security_audit.summary: No credential access, network calls, or execution hooks were found in the skill files. Code focuses on plotting styles and local file exports. The risk profile is safe.

content.value_statement: Scientific figures often fail journal requirements for size, format, and accessibility. This skill guides you to build publication-ready plots with correct styling and export settings.
actual_capabilities: Apply publication matplotlib style presets and palettes
Configure figures for Nature, Science, Cell, PLOS, ACS, and IEEE sizing
Export figures in PDF, EPS, TIFF, and PNG with DPI control
Check figure size compliance against journal specifications
Provide colorblind-friendly palettes and colormap guidance
Offer multi-panel layout examples with panel labeling
limitations: Does not generate or analyze data for you
Requires matplotlib and related libraries to be installed
Plotly static export needs kaleido installed
Journal requirements can change and must be verified

use_cases.title: Prepare a figure for submission
use_cases.description: Format a multi-panel figure to meet Nature or Science size, font, and export requirements.

use_cases.title: Standardize lab figure styles
use_cases.description: Apply a shared publication style and palette across figures for consistent manuscripts.

use_cases.title: Create accessible statistical plots
use_cases.description: Build colorblind-friendly plots with error bars and clear labeling for reports.

prompt_templates.title: Start with a clean plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a publication-ready line plot template in matplotlib with axis labels, error bars, and colorblind-safe colors.

prompt_templates.title: Journal sizing check
prompt_templates.prompt: Check if my 3.5 by 2.5 inch figure fits Nature single-column requirements and suggest adjustments.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-panel layout
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a 2x2 multi-panel layout with panel labels and consistent spacing for a journal submission.

prompt_templates.title: Journal-specific export
prompt_templates.prompt: Export a figure for Cell as line art with correct DPI and file formats, and explain the chosen settings.

output_examples.input: Format a Nature single-column figure and list the export settings.
output: Set figure width to 89 mm with 4:3 aspect ratio.
Applied Nature style with smaller font sizes and thin lines.
Exported as PDF at 600 DPI for combination figures.
Suggested EPS at 1000 DPI for pure line art.

best_practices: Use vector formats for plots and TIFF or PNG for images
Apply colorblind-safe palettes and test grayscale output
Verify figure size against target journal specs before export
anti_patterns: Using JPEG for plots or line art
Relying only on color without markers or line styles
Exporting raster images below journal DPI requirements

faq.question: Is this compatible with my setup?
faq.answer: It works with matplotlib, seaborn, and plotly in Python. You must install these libraries first.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: It does not create data or perform statistical analysis. It focuses on styling, layout, and export.

faq.question: Can I integrate it with my workflow?
faq.answer: Yes. Import the helper scripts or style files into your notebooks or pipelines.

faq.question: Does it access my data or credentials?
faq.answer: No. The skill uses local plotting settings and file exports only.

faq.question: What if a style does not apply?
faq.answer: Check journal rules, then adjust font sizes, DPI, and figure width using the provided helpers.

faq.question: How does it compare to a general plotting guide?
faq.answer: It includes journal sizing, export presets, and colorblind palettes focused on publication standards.
